questions.question: What is the fundamental difference between distance and displacement?
options: Distance is always larger than displacement
Distance is a vector, displacement is a scalar
Distance is total path length, displacement is straight-line from start to end
They are measured in different units
questions.explanation: Distance is the total path length traveled (scalar), while displacement is the straight-line distance from starting point to ending point, including direction (vector).

questions.question: A person walks 12 meters East, then 8 meters West. What is the total distance traveled?
questions.explanation: Distance is the sum of all path lengths: 12 m + 8 m = 20 meters. This is scalar addition.

questions.question: In the same scenario (12m East, then 8m West), what is the displacement?
questions.explanation: Displacement is the net position change: 12m East + 8m West = 4m East. This is vector addition considering direction.

questions.question: Which quantity can be zero even when distance is not zero?
questions.explanation: Displacement can be zero when an object returns to its starting point, even though it traveled a non-zero distance.

questions.question: A car drives 25 km North, then 18 km South. What is the total distance traveled?
questions.explanation: Distance = 25 km + 18 km = 43 km (scalar addition)

questions.question: What is the displacement of the car that drove 25 km North then 18 km South?
questions.explanation: Displacement = 25 km North + 18 km South = 7 km North (vector addition)

questions.question: Which of the following is always true?
questions.explanation: Distance is always greater than or equal to displacement. They are equal only when the path is straight in one direction.

questions.question: A student walks around a rectangular field: 60m North, 40m East, 60m South, then 40m West. What is the total distance?
questions.explanation: Distance = 60 + 40 + 60 + 40 = 200 meters (scalar sum of all segments)

questions.question: What is the student's displacement after walking around the rectangular field?
questions.explanation: The student returns to the starting point, so displacement = 0 meters.

questions.question: Which quantity tells you how far you are from where you started?
questions.explanation: Displacement tells you both the straight-line distance and direction from your starting point to your current position.

questions.question: A person walks 15 meters East, then 8 meters North. What is the total distance traveled?
questions.explanation: Distance = 15 m + 8 m = 23 meters (scalar addition)

questions.question: What is the magnitude of displacement for the person who walked 15m East then 8m North?
questions.explanation: Displacement magnitude = √(15² + 8²) = √(225 + 64) = √289 = 17 meters

questions.question: Which quantity is represented by the actual path taken?
questions.explanation: Distance follows the actual path taken, while displacement only considers the start and end points.

questions.question: A runner completes one lap around a 300m circular track. What is their distance traveled?
questions.explanation: Distance = 300 meters (one complete lap)

questions.question: What is the runner's displacement after one complete lap?
questions.explanation: Displacement = 0 meters (back to starting point)

questions.question: Which of these measurements could represent displacement?
questions.explanation: Displacement is a vector quantity, so it requires both magnitude and direction: '18 meters West'

questions.question: A car travels 30 km North, then 30 km South. What is the relationship between distance and displacement?
questions.explanation: Distance = 60 km, Displacement = 0 km, so Distance > Displacement

questions.question: What are the units for both distance and displacement?
questions.explanation: Both distance and displacement are measured in units of length, such as meters (m).

questions.question: A person walks 12m East, then 12m North, then 12m West. What is the total distance?
questions.explanation: Distance = 12 + 12 + 12 = 36 meters (scalar sum)

questions.question: What is the displacement for the person who walked 12m East, 12m North, then 12m West?
questions.explanation: The person ends up 12 meters North of the starting point, so displacement = 12 meters North.
